article.title: Corona_Australis
article.paragraph: Corona AustralisIPAc-enkɵˈroʊnə_ɒˈstreɪlɨsorCorona AustrinaIPAc-enkɵˈroʊnə_ɒˈstraɪnəsfnBagnall2012170is aconstellationin theSouthern Celestial Hemisphere. Its Latin name means "southern crown", and it is the southern counterpart ofCorona Borealis, the northern crown. One of the 48 constellations listed by the 2nd-century astronomerPtolemy, it remains one of the 88 modern constellations. The Ancient Greeks saw Corona Australis as a wreath rather than a crown and associated it withSagittarius (constellation)SagittariusorCentaurus. Other cultures have likened the pattern to a turtle, ostrich nest, a tent, or even a hut belonging to arock hyrax.

Although fainter than its namesake, the oval- or horseshoe-shaped pattern of its brighter stars renders it distinctive.Alpha Coronae AustralisAlphaandBeta Coronae Australisare the two brightest stars with an apparent magnitude of around 4.1.Epsilon Coronae Australisis the brightest example of aW Ursae Majoris variablein the southern sky. Lying alongside theMilky Way, Corona Australis contains one of the closestStar formationstar-forming regionsto our Solar Systema dustydark nebulaknown as theCorona Australis Molecular Cloud, lying about 430 light years away. Within it are stars at the earliest stages of their lifespan. The variable starsR Coronae AustralisRandTY Coronae Australislight up parts of the nebula, which varies in brightness accordingly.
article.heading: Characteristics
article.paragraph: Corona Australis is a small constellation bordered bySagittarius (constellation)Sagittariusto the north,Scorpiusto the west,Telescopiumto the south, andAra (constellation)Arato the southwest. The three-letter abbreviation for the constellation, as adopted by theInternational Astronomical Unionin 1922, is 'CrA'.sfnRussell1922469The official constellation boundaries, as set byEugne Joseph DelporteEugne Delportein 1930, are defined by a polygon of four segments (illustrated in infobox). In theequatorial coordinate system, theright ascensioncoordinates of these borders lie betweenRA1758.3andRA1919.0, while thedeclinationcoordinates are between 36.77 and 45.52.sfnIAU, ''The Constellations'', Corona AustralisCovering 128 square degrees, Corona Australisculminationculminatesat midnight around the 30th of JunerefnMalin Frew 1995 p218and ranks 80th in area.sfnRidpath, ''Constellations''Only visible at latitudes south of 53 north,sfnRidpath, ''Constellations''Corona Australis cannot be seen from the British Isles as it lies too far south,refnMoore & Tirion 1997 pp164but it can be seen from southern EuroperefnMoore 2005 p202and readily from the southern United States.refnMoore 'Stargazing' 2000 p86
article.heading: Notable features

link.part: The constellation Corona Australis as it can be seen by the naked eye.

article.paragraph: While not a bright constellation, Corona Australis is nonetheless distinctive due to its easily identifiable pattern of stars,sfnRidpathTirion2007126–127which has been described as horseshoe-refnFalkner 2011 p100or oval-shaped.refnMalin Frew 1995 p218Though it has no stars brighter than magnitude 2.4, it still has 21 stars visible to the unaided eye (brighter than magnitude 5.5),sfnBakich1995130making it the second-brightest constellation.sfnBakich Podcast26 August 2010Nicolas Louis de Lacailleused the Greek letters Alpha through to Lambda to label the most prominent eleven stars in the constellation, designating two stars as Eta and omitting Iota altogether.Mu Coronae Australis, a yellow star of spectral type G5.5III and apparent magnitude 5.21,sfnSIMBAD Mu Coronae Australiswas labelled byJohann Elert Bodeand retained byBenjamin Apthorp GouldBenjamin Gould, who deemed it bright enough to warrant naming.sfnWagman2003114–115
article.heading: Stars

template.arg: List of stars in Corona Australis

article.paragraph: The only star in the constellation to have received a name isAlpha Coronae AustralisAlfecca Meridiana or Alpha CrA. The name combines theArabicname of the constellation with theLatinfor "southern".sfnAllen1963172–173In Arabic,Alfeccameans "break", and refers to the shape of both Corona Australis and Corona Borealis.sfnKaler, ''Alfecca Meridiana''Also called simply "Meridiana",sfnBagnall2012170it is a whitemain sequencestar located 130 light years away from Earth,sfnRidpathTirion2007126–127with anapparent magnitudeof 4.10 andStellar classificationspectral typeA2Va.sfnSIMBAD Alpha Coronae AustralisA rapidly rotating star, it spins at almost 200 km per second at its equator, making a complete revolution in around 14 hours.sfnRoyerZorecGómez2007463Like the starVega, it hasInfrared excessexcess infrared radiation, which indicates it may be ringed by a disk of dust.sfnKaler, ''Alfecca Meridiana''It is currently amain-sequence star, but will eventuallystellar evolutionevolveinto awhite dwarf; currently, it has a luminosity 31 times greater, and a radius and mass of 2.3 times that of the Sun.sfnKaler, ''Alfecca Meridiana''Beta Coronae Australisis an orangegiant stargiant510 light years from Earth.sfnRidpathTirion2007126–127Its spectral type is K0II, and it is of apparent magnitude 4.11.sfnSIMBAD Beta Coronae AustralisSince its formation, it has evolved from aB-type starto aK-type star. Itsluminosity classplaces it as abright giant; its luminosity is 730 times that of the Sun,sfnKaler, ''Beta Coronae Australis''designating it one of the highest-luminosity K0-type stars visible to the naked eye.sfnBagnall2012170100 million years old, it has a radius of 43solar radiussolar radii(Solar radius) and a mass of between 4.5 and 5solar masses(Solar mass). Alpha and Beta are so similar as to be indistinguishable in brightness to the naked eye.sfnKaler, ''Beta Coronae Australis''

Some of the more prominent double stars includeGamma Coronae Australisa pair of yellowish white stars 58 light years away from Earth, which orbit each other every 122 years. Widening since 1990, the two stars can be seen as separate with a 100 mm aperture telescope;sfnRidpathTirion2007126–127they are separated by 1.3 arcseconds at an angle of 61 degrees.sfnMooreRees2011413They have a combined visual magnitude of 4.2;sfnSIMBAD LTT 7565each component is an F8Vdwarf starwith a magnitude of 5.01.sfnSIMBAD HR 7226sfnSIMBAD HR 7227Epsilon Coronae Australisis anBinary star#Eclipsing binarieseclipsing binarybelonging to a class of stars known asW Ursae Majoris variables. These star systems are known asContact binarycontact binariesas the component stars are so close together they touch. Varying by a quarter of a magnitude around an average apparent magnitude of 4.83 every seven hours, the star system lies 98 light years away.sfnKaler, ''Epsilon Coronae Australis''Its spectral type is F4VFe-0.8+.sfnSIMBAD Epsilon Coronae AustralisAt the southern end of the crown asterism are the starsEta Coronae AustralisEtaandEta Coronae Australis, which form anoptical double.sfnMotzNathanson1991254–255Of magnitude 5.1 and 5.5, they are separable with the naked eye and are both white.sfnStreicher2008135–139Kappa Coronae Australisis an easily resolved optical doublethe components are of apparent magnitudes 6.3 and 5.7 and are 1700 and 490 light years away respectively.sfnRidpathTirion2007126–127They appear at an angle of 359 degrees, separated by 21.6 arcseconds.sfnMooreRees2011413Kappa2 Coronae AustralisKappais actually the brighter of the pair and is more bluish white,sfnStreicher2008135–139with a spectral type of B9V,sfnSIMBAD HR 6953whileKappa1 Coronae AustralisKappais of spectral type A0III.sfnSIMBAD HR 6952Lying 202 light years away,Lambda Coronae Australisis a double splittable in small telescopes. The primary is a white star of spectral type A2Vn and magnitude of 5.1,sfnSIMBAD Lambda Coronae Australiswhile the companion star has a magnitude of 9.7.sfnRidpathTirion2007126–127The two components are separated by 29.2 arcseconds at an angle of 214 degrees.sfnMooreRees2011413

Zeta Coronae Australisis a rapidly rotating main sequence star with an apparent magnitude of 4.8, 221.7 light years from Earth. The star has blurred lines in its hydrogen spectrum due to its rotation.sfnMotzNathanson1991254–255Its spectral type is B9V.sfnSIMBAD Zeta Coronae AustralisTheta Coronae Australislies further to the west, a yellow giant of spectral type G8III and apparent magnitude 4.62.sfnSIMBAD Theta Coronae AustralisCorona Australis harboursRX J1856.5-3754, an isolatedneutron starthat is thought to lie 140 (40) parsecs, or 460 (130) light years, away, with a diameter of 14 km.sfnHo Wynn C. G. et al.2007It was once suspected to be aQuark star#Strange starstrange star,sfnDrake, Jeremy J. et al.2002but this has been discounted.sfnHo Wynn C. G. et al.2007
article.heading: Deep sky objects

link.part: The R Coronae Australis region imaged with the Wide Field Imager atESO'sLa Silla Observatory. According to ESO, "The light blue nebulosity seen in this picture is mostly due to the reflection of starlight off small dust particles." "A prominent dark lane crosses the image from the centre to the bottom left. Here the visible light emitted by the stars that are forming inside the cloud is completely absorbed by the dust. These objects could only be detected by observing at longer wavelengths, by using a camera that can detect infrared radiation."

article.paragraph: In the north of the constellation is theCorona Australis Molecular Cloud, a darkmolecular cloudwith many embeddedreflection nebulae,sfnKaler, ''Beta Coronae Australis''includingNGC 6729,NGC 67267, andIC 4812.sfnMalin2010Astar formationstar-forming regionof aroundSolar mass7000,sfnKaler, ''Beta Coronae Australis''it containsHerbigHaro objects(protostars) and some very young stars.sfnMalin2010About 430 light years (130 parsecs) away, it is one of the closest star-forming regions to our solar system.sfnReipurth2008735The related NGC 6726 and 6727, along with unrelated NGC 6729, were first recorded byJohann Friedrich Julius Schmidtin 1865.sfnSteinicke2010176TheCoronet cluster, about 554 light years (170 parsecs) away at the edge of theGould Belt, is also used in studying star andprotoplanetary diskformation.cite journalSicilia-AguilarAurora HenningThomas Juha´szAttila BouwmanJeroen GarmireGordon GarmireAudrey VERY LOW MASS OBJECTS IN THE CORONET CLUSTER: THE REALM OF THE TRANSITION DISKSThe Astrophysical Journal10 November 2008http://iopscience.iop.org/0004-637X/687/2/1145/pdf/0004-637X_687_2_1145.pdf10.1086/5919320807.25042008ApJ...687.1145S

R Coronae Australisis an irregular variable star ranging from magnitudes 9.7 to 13.9.refnO'Meara 2002 pp273++Blue-white, it is of spectral type B5IIIpe.sfnSIMBAD R Coronae AustralisA very young star, it is still accumulating interstellar material.sfnMalin2010It is obscured by, and illuminates, the surrounding nebula, NGC 6729, which brightens and darkens with it.refnO'Meara 2002 pp273++The nebula is often compared to acometfor its appearance in a telescope, as its length is five times its width.sfnBakich Podcast25 June 2009S Coronae Australisis a G-class dwarf in the same field as R and is aT Tauri star.sfnMotzNathanson1991254–255Nearby, another young variable star,TY Coronae Australis, illuminates another nebula: reflection nebula NGC 67267. TY Coronae Australis ranges irregularly between magnitudes 8.7 and 12.4,and the brightness of the nebula varies with it.refnO'Meara 2002 pp273++Blue-white, it is of spectral type B8e.sfnSIMBAD TY Coronae AustralisThe largest young stars in the region, R, S,T Coronae AustralisT, TY andVV Coronae Australis, are all ejecting jets of material which cause surrounding dust and gas to coalesce and form HerbigHaro objects, many of which have been identified nearby.sfnWangMundtHenningApai2004Lying adjacent to the nebulosity is theglobular clusterknown asNGC 6723, which is actually in the neighbouring constellation of Sagittarius and is much much further away.refnCoe 2007 p105

Near Epsilon and Gamma Coronae Australis isBernes 157, adark nebulaand star forming region. It is a large nebula, 55 by 18 arcminutes, that possesses several stars around magnitude 13. These stars have been dimmed by up to 8 magnitudes by its dust clouds.sfnBakich2010266

IC 1297is aplanetary nebulaof apparent magnitude 10.7, which appears as a green-hued roundish object in higher-powered amateur instruments.refnGriffiths 2012 p132The nebula surrounds the variable star RU Coronae Australis, which has an average apparent magnitude of 12.9sfnMoore, ''Data Book''2000367–368and is a WC classWolfRayet star.sfnSIMBAD RU Coronae AustralisIC 1297 is small, at only 7 arcseconds in diameter; it has been described as "a square with rounded edges" in the eyepiece, elongated in the north-south direction.sfnBakich2010270Descriptions of its color encompass blue, blue-tinged green, and green-tinged blue.sfnBakich2010270

Corona Australis' location near the Milky Way means that galaxies are uncommonly seen.NGC 6768is a magnitude 11.2 object 35 south of IC 1297. It is made up of two galaxies merging,sfnStreicher2008135–139one of which is an elongatedelliptical galaxyof classification E4 and the other alenticular galaxyof classification S0.sfnNASA/IPAC NGC 6768IC 4808is a galaxy of apparent magnitude 12.9 located on the border of Corona Australis with the neighbouring constellation of Telescopium and 3.9 degrees west-southwest ofBeta Sagittarii. However, amateur telescopes will only show a suggestion of its spiral structure. It is 1.9 arcminutes by 0.8 arcminutes. The central area of the galaxy does appear brighter in an amateur instrument, which shows it to be tilted northeast-southwest.sfnBakich Podcast18 August 2011

Southeast of Theta and southwest of Eta lies theopen clusterESO 281-SC24, which is composed of the yellow 9th magnitude star GSC 7914 178 1 and five 10th to 11th magnitude stars.sfnStreicher2008135–139Halfway between Theta Coronae Australis andTheta Scorpiiis the dense globular clusterNGC 6541. Described as between magnitude 6.3refnO'Meara 2002 pp273++and magnitude 6.6,sfnMooreRees2011413it is visible in binoculars and small telescopes. Around 22000 light years away, it is around 100 light years in diameter.refnO'Meara 2002 pp273++It is estimated to be around 14 billion years old.refnO'Meara 2011 p322NGC 6541 appears 13.1 arcminutes in diameter and is somewhat resolvable in large amateur instruments; a 12-inch telescope reveals approximately 100 stars but the core remains unresolved.sfnBakich Podcast5 July 2012
article.heading: Meteor showers
article.paragraph: TheCorona Australidsare a meteor shower that takes place between 14 and 18 March each year, peaking around 16 March.refnSherrod Koed 2003 p50This meteor shower does not have a high peak hourly rate. In 1953 and 1956, observers noted a maximum of 6 meteors per hour and 4 meteors per hour respectively; in 1955 the shower was "barely resolved".sfnWeiss1957300However, in 1992, astronomers detected a peak rate of 45 meteors per hour.sfnRogersKeay1993274The Corona Australids' rate varies from year to year.sfnWeiss1957302sfnEllyettKeay1956479At only six days, the shower's duration is particularly short,sfnRogersKeay1993274and itsmeteoroidsare small; the stream is devoid of large meteoroids. The Corona Australids were first seen with the unaided eye in 1935 and first observed withradarin 1955.sfnEllyettKeay1956479Corona Australid meteors have an entry velocity of 45 kilometers per second.sfnJenniskens19941007In 2006, a shower originating near Beta Coronae Australis was designated as the Beta Coronae Australids. They appear in May, the same month as a nearby shower known as the May Microscopids, but the two showers have different trajectories and are unlikely to be related.sfnJopek et al.2010871–872
article.heading: History

link.part: Corona Australis depicted in the ''Atlas Coelestis'' ofJohn Flamsteed

article.paragraph: Corona Australis may have been recorded by ancientMesopotamiansin theMUL.APIN, as a constellation called MA.GUR ("The Bark"). However, this constellation, adjacent to SUHUR.MASH ("The Goat-Fish", modernCapricornus (constellation)Capricornus), may instead have been modernEpsilon Sagittarii. As a part of the southern sky, MA.GUR was one of the fifteen "stars ofEa (god)Ea".sfnRogers199819

In the 3rd century BC, the GreekDidacticismdidacticpoetAratuswrote of, but did not name the constellation,sfnBakich199583instead calling the two crowns (Stephanoi). The Greek astronomerPtolemydescribed the constellation in the 2nd century AD, though with the inclusion ofAlpha Telescopii, since transferred to Telescopium.sfnRidpath, ''Star Tales'' Corona AustralisAscribing 13 stars to the constellation,refnMalin Frew 1995 p218he named it (Stephanos notios), "Southern Wreath", while other authors associated it with either Sagittarius (having fallen off his head) or Centaurus; with the former, it was calledCorona Sagittarii.sfnAllen1963172–174Similarly, the Romans called Corona Australis the "Golden Crown of Sagittarius".sfnSimpson2012148It was known asParvum Coelum("Canopy", "Little Sky") in the 5th century.sfnMotzNathanson1988254The 18th-century French astronomerJrme Lalandegave it the namesSertum Australe("Southern Garland")sfnAllen1963172–174sfnMotzNathanson1988254andOrbiculus Capitis, while German poet and authorPhilipp von ZesenPhilippus Caesiuscalled itCorolla("Little Crown") orSpira Australis("Southern Coil"), and linked it with the Crown of Eternal Life from the New Testament. Seventeenth-century celestial cartographerJulius Schillerlinked it to the Diadem of Solomon.sfnAllen1963172–174Sometimes, Corona Australis was not the wreath of Sagittarius but arrows held in his hand.sfnMotzNathanson1988254

Corona Australis has been associated with the myth ofDionysisBacchusandSemeleStimula.Jupiter (mythology)Jupiterhad impregnated Stimula, causingJuno (mythology)Junoto become jealous. Juno convinced Stimula to ask Jupiter to appear in his full splendor, which the mortal woman could not handle, causing her to burn. After Bacchus, Stimula's unborn child, became an adult and the god of wine, he honored his deceased mother by placing a wreath in the sky.sfnStaal1988232–233

InChinese astronomy, the stars of Corona Australis are located within theBlack Tortoise (Chinese constellation)Black Tortoise of the North(,Bi Fng Xun W).sfnAEEA2006The constellation itself was known asti'en pieh("Heavenly Turtle") and during theWestern Zhouperiod, marked the beginning of winter. However,Axial precessionprecessionover time has meant that the "Heavenly River" (Milky Way) became the more accurate marker to the ancient Chinese and hence supplanted the turtle in this role.refnPorter 1996 pp35–36Arabic names for Corona Australis includeAl ubbah"the Tortoise",Al ib"the Tent" orAl Ud al Na'm"the Ostrich Nest".sfnAllen1963172–174sfnMotzNathanson1988254It was later given the nameAl Ikll al Janbiyyah, which the European authorsEdmund ChilmeadChilmead,Giovanni Battista RiccioliRiccioliand Caesius transliterated as Alachil Elgenubi, Elkleil Elgenubi and Aladil Algenubi respectively.sfnAllen1963172–174

TheXam languageXamspeakingSan peopleof South Africa knew the constellation asnabbe ta !nu"house of branches"owned originally by the Dassie (rock hyrax), and the star pattern depicting people sitting in a semicircle around a fire.sfnLloyd1873

The indigenousWergaiaBoorongpeople of northwestern Victoria saw it asWon, a boomerang thrown byTotyarguil(Altair).sfnHamacherFrew2010TheAranda peopleof Central Australia saw Corona Australis as aCoolamon (vessel)coolamoncarrying a baby, which was accidentally dropped to earth by a group of sky-women dancing in the Milky Way. The impact of the coolamon createdGosses Bluff crater, 175 km west ofAlice Springs.sfnHamacher28 March 2011TheTorres Strait Islanderssaw Corona Australis as part of a larger constellation encompassing part of Sagittarius and the tip ofScorpius (constellation)Scorpius's tail; thePleiadesandOrion (constellation)Orionwere also associated. This constellation was Tagai's canoe, crewed by the Pleiades, called theUsiam, and Orion, called theSeg. The myth of Tagai says that he was in charge of this canoe, but his crewmen consumed all of the supplies onboard without asking permission. Enraged, Tagai bound the Usiam with a rope and tied them to the side of the boat, then threw them overboard. Scorpius's tail represents aRemorasuckerfish, whileEta Sagittariiand Theta Coronae Australis mark the bottom of the canoe.sfnStaal1988223–224On the island ofFutuna (Wallis and Futuna)Futuna, the figure of Corona Australis was calledTanumaand in theTuamotus, it was calledNa Kaua-ki-Tonga.sfnMakemson1941281
